data.title: This Man Must Die (1969)
data.meta_description: When his young son is killed in a hit and run accident, Charles Thenier resolves to hunt down and murder the killer. By chance, Thenier makes the acquaintance of an actress, Helène Lanson, who was in the car at the time of the accident. He then meets Helène’s brother-in-law, Paul Decourt, a truly horrible individual.
data.text:
“This Man Must Die” is the murder where the formerly genre-fluid director Claude Chabrol turned serial with a commitment to crime thrillers.

“Must Die,” appropriately, possesses a knife sharp edge of competency. The film stars Michel Duchaussoy as a writer who obsesses over finding the driver of a hit and run accident that killed his young son.

On concept alone, the work seems a sort of standard revenge-mystery plot that could be played out these days by anyone from Ryan Gosling to Liam Neeson. Chabrol and Duchaussoy though, commit to a remarkable show of mundanity as they go about the business of equaling out justice.

Chabrol's study of retribution as movie motif, one of his more ideally structured movies. Very chilling and unwilling to allow easy identification. Innocence is shattered in the opening scene and from there on it is a gam of chairs of destructive feelings. The mai character is a writer and a diary plays a key role, and one must say forms of storytelling are very central to the movie appeal. Midway through it, Jean Yanne pops up as the titular beast in a remarkable odious performance and in typical Chabrolian dark humor the movie stops to ponder how much worse this obviously horrible man is than all the other dark impulses the movie is charting. 9th Claude Chabrol (after Le Boucher, La Cérémonie, Blood Relatives, Landru, Web of Passion, Just Before Nightfall, Violette Noizère and Death Rite)

Revenge is perhaps worst when it's thwarted, when your desire for karmic justice is rendered impotent by the situations around you. You crave the restorative assurance that you have power to take back what you lost, but to lose that? Well, you're even less than you once were. And poor Charles. All that hard work, all those weeks of tracking the car that killed his son, all that subtle manipulation to find the person who caused his misery. And for what? Steve's Priority Watchlist Project

I've been slower on the uptake in watching more Claude Chabrol films than I should be considering where it appears his career ultimately took him.

He seems to be labelled, especially in the second half of his career, a director of thrillers. That's probably a simplification of what he did - he seemed to almost strangle the life out of the traditional thriller clichés in search of a more grounded and 'realistic' approach.
